segments.pli: Assuttha no tumhe, bhikkhave, rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ jarasiṅgālassa vassamānassā”ti?
segments.en: Mendicants, did you hear an old jackal howling at the crack of dawn?”

segments.pli: “Eso kho, bhikkhave, jarasiṅgālo ukkaṇḍakena nāma rogajātena phuṭṭho neva bilagato ramati, na rukkhamūlagato ramati, na ajjhokāsagato ramati;
segments.en: “That old jackal has the disease called mange. He’s not happy in his den, or at the root of a tree, or out in the open.

segments.pli: yena yena gacchati, yattha yattha tiṭṭhati, yattha yattha nisīdati, yattha yattha nipajjati; tattha tattha anayabyasanaṃ āpajjati.
segments.en: Wherever he goes, stands, sits, or lies down he meets with tragedy and disaster.

segments.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhikkhu lābhasakkārasilokena abhibhūto pariyādiṇṇacitto neva suññāgāragato ramati, na rukkhamūlagato ramati, na ajjhokāsagato ramati;
segments.en: In the same way, take a certain mendicant whose mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity. They’re not happy in an empty hut, at the root of a tree, or out in the open.

segments.pli: yena yena gacchati, yattha yattha tiṭṭhati, yattha yattha nisīdati, yattha yattha nipajjati; tattha tattha anayabyasanaṃ āpajjati.
segments.en: Wherever they go, stand, sit, or lie down they meet with tragedy and disaster.

segments.pli: Evaṃ dāruṇo kho, bhikkhave, lābhasakkārasiloko … pe …
segments.en: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

suttaplex.blurb: A mendicant who is proud on account of their material possessions, honor, and praise is never at peace, like a mangy jackal.
